articles.headline: Executive at Monsanto Wins Global Food Honor
articles.snippet: Robert Fraley of Monsanto shares the prize with two other scientists prominent in the field of genetically modified crops.
articles.abstract: Robert Fraley of Monsanto shares the prize with two other scientists prominent in the field of genetically modified crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to agriculture, the World Food Prize is the equivalent of the Oscars.

articles.headline: Optimistic Fed Outlines an End to Its Stimulus
articles.snippet: Policy makers, more confident about the recovery, said they intended to reduce their monetary stimulus program later this year if unemployment continues to decline.
articles.abstract: Policy makers, more confident about the recovery, said they intended to reduce their monetary stimulus program later this year if unemployment continues to decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, increasingly confident in the durability of economic growth, expects to start pulling back later this year from its efforts to stimulate the economy, the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: Microsoft Adds Office for iPhone. Yawn.
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s application falls short of duplicating the everyday functions of Word, Excel and PowerPoint. Some outside apps do it better.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s application falls short of duplicating the everyday functions of Word, Excel and PowerPoint. Some outside apps do it better.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anticlimax (noun) 1. An event or conclusion that is far less important, powerful or striking than expected. 2. The release of Microsoft Office for the iPhone.

articles.headline: Anxiety in Detroit Over a Prized Car Trove
articles.snippet: The possibility of a bankruptcy filing by Detroit has raised concerns about the fate of 62 classic cars managed by the city’s historical society.
articles.abstract: The possibility of a bankruptcy filing by Detroit has raised concerns about the fate of 62 classic cars managed by the city’s historical society.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As this debt-ridden city lurches toward a possible bankruptcy filing, residents and workers have been locked in a grim faceoff with creditors over how to preserve what remains of their services and benefits.
articles.byline: By Jaclyn Trop and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Stocks Slide on Fears of Cuts to Fed’s Bond-Buying Program
articles.snippet: The steep market declines on Wednesday underscored the fears circulating through trading desks that the economy is not strong enough to do without the Fed’s support.
articles.abstract: The steep market declines on Wednesday underscored the fears circulating through trading desks that the economy is not strong enough to do without the Fed’s support.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben S. Bernanke’s confidence in the United States economy did not kill the worm of doubt that has been gnawing at markets.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Is Said to Plan Inquiry of Frivolous Patent Lawsuits
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission plans to issue subpoenas to companies that are patent trolls, meaning that they buy large portfolios of technology patents and use them to sue other entities.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission plans to issue subpoenas to companies that are patent trolls, meaning that they buy large portfolios of technology patents and use them to sue other entities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission is expected on Thursday to recommend a sweeping investigation of “patent trolls,” companies that buy large portfolios of technology patents and use them to sue software designers and makers of products like smartphones and tablet computers, people briefed on the inquiry said.

articles.headline: Strategist Out of Closet and Into Fray, This Time for Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: Ken Mehlman, the strategist who ran President George W. Bush’s re-election bid, is trying to convince Republicans that gay marriage is consistent with conservative values.
articles.abstract: Ken Mehlman, the strategist who ran President George W. Bush’s re-election bid, is trying to convince Republicans that gay marriage is consistent with conservative values.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court considers overturning California’s ban on same-sex marriage, gay people await a ruling that could change their lives. But the case has already transformed one gay man: Ken Mehlman, the once-closeted Republican operative who orchestrated President George W. Bush’s 2004 re-election on a platform that included opposition to same-sex marriage.

articles.headline: Sizing Up Big Data, Broadening Beyond the Internet
articles.snippet: Internet companies were just the start. Virtually every field, from science to sports to public health, is being transformed by data-driven discovery and decision-making.
articles.abstract: Internet companies were just the start. Virtually every field, from science to sports to public health, is being transformed by data-driven discovery and decision-making.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his young career, Jeffrey Hammerbacher has been a scout on the frontiers of the data economy.

articles.headline: Web’s Reach Binds N.S.A. and Silicon Valley Leaders
articles.snippet: Technology experts and former intelligence officials say the rise of data mining, both as an industry and as a crucial intelligence tool, has created a complex reality.
articles.abstract: Technology experts and former intelligence officials say the rise of data mining, both as an industry and as a crucial intelligence tool, has created a complex reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Max Kelly, the chief security officer for Facebook, left the social media company in 2010, he did not go to Google, Twitter or a similar Silicon Valley concern. Instead the man who was responsible for protecting the personal information of Facebook’s more than one billion users from outside attacks went to work for another giant institution that manages and analyzes large pools of data: the National Security Agency.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Credit Tightens in China as Central Bank Takes a Hard Line
articles.snippet: The interest rates that Chinese banks must pay to borrow money from each other surged to record highs as the government put pressure on speculators.
articles.abstract: The interest rates that Chinese banks must pay to borrow money from each other surged to record highs as the government put pressure on speculators.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s financial system is in the throes of a cash squeeze as the government tries to restructure the economy and punish speculators, with interbank lending rates spiking on Thursday and bank-to-bank borrowing nearly stalled.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and David Barboza

articles.headline: Regulator in New York Sets Tough Bank Fine
articles.snippet: The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ reached a settlement with the top financial regulator for New York State over accusations that it had sent about $100 billion in tainted money through the United States.
articles.abstract: The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ reached a settlement with the top financial regulator for New York State over accusations that it had sent about $100 billion in tainted money through the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took just $8.6 million for Japan’s largest bank to settle with federal regulators in Washington who accused it of routing tainted money through the United States.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Sweeping Protests in Brazil Pull In an Array of Grievances
articles.snippet: More than a million people joined the protests late Thursday in the country’s biggest demonstrations yet, an uprising fueled by the angry rejection of politics as usual.
articles.abstract: More than a million people joined the protests late Thursday in the country’s biggest demonstrations yet, an uprising fueled by the angry rejection of politics as usual.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Just a few weeks ago, Mayara Vivian felt pretty good when a few hundred people showed up for a protest she helped organize to deride the government over a proposed bus fare increase. She had been trying to prod Brazilians into the streets since 2005, when she was only 15, and by now she thought she knew what to expect.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and William Neuman
